description: Number of rows in which n appears in Pascal's triangle (A007318).
comments: a(A180058(n)) = n and a(m) < n for m < A180058(n); a(A182237(n)) = 2; a(A098565(n)) = 3. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 24 2012
references: L. Comtet, Advanced Combinatorics, Reidel, 1974, p. 93, #47.
C. S. Ogilvy, Tomorrow's Math. 2nd ed., Oxford Univ. Press, 1972, p. 96.
links: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=2..10000
D. Singmaster, How often does an integer occur as a binomial coefficient?, Amer. Math. Monthly, 78 (1971), 385-386.
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Pascal's Triangle
Index entries for triangles and arrays related to Pascal's triangle
example: 6 appears in both row 4 and row 6 in Pascal's triangle, therefore a(6)=2.
mathematica: nmax = 101; A007318 = Table[Binomial[n, k], {n, 0, nmax}, {k, 0, n}]; a[n_] := Position[A007318, n][[All, 1]] // Union // Length; Table[a[n], {n, 2, nmax}] (* _Jean-Fran√ßois Alcover_, Sep 09 2013 *)
prog: (Haskell)a059233 n = length $ filter (n `elem`) $                            take (fromInteger n) $ tail a007318_tabla059233_list = map a059233 [2..]-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 24 2012
author: _Fabian Rothelius_, Jan 20 2001
